text: Do you pronounce it as pekhan or peecan?
Or maybe its peekan or pickan?

Whatever it may be, I’m almost positive
you’ve seen a surplus of these pies at your

local bakery or grocery store during this
time of year.

And if you’re from Texas, I’m sure you’ve
seen them year round.

While pecan pie was likely invented in the
19th century, the nuts themselves have a much
older and richer American history.

With pecans being the only tree nut native
to north America, the origin of them can be
traced back as early as the 1500s.

The word “pecan” actually comes from the
Algonquin tribe’s word “pacane” which

translates to “nuts requiring a stone to
crack”.

Having grown along the Mississippi, pecans
were heavily used and valued by native tribes.

They were especially ideal for foraging due
to its longevity, even after falling from
the tree.

Pecans themselves faced some hardship as they
grew in popularity around the 1800s.

The nuts could result in wildly different
flavors, despite being harvested from the
same tree.

The solution to this was grafting branches
to an already existing tree.

A task that was done remarkably well by an
enslaved gardener named Antoine, of whom there
is regretfully very little history recorded.

But his work did not go unrecognized as 30
years later, nuts produced from his grafted

trees won best pecan at the Philadelphia centennial
world fair.

They soon became known as centennial pecan
trees and were the basis of the commercial
pecan industry.

And soon after that, we started seeing the
first pecan pie recipes popping up.

Though no single original recipe can be traced,
one of the earliest instances of pecan pie

appeared in a St. Louis cookbook in 1898,
having been submitted by a Texan woman.

Though, it’s not quite the pecan pie we
know of today.

Rather than being sickly sweet, it was more
custard like and often had the inclusions
of milk and or raisins.
Pecans weren’t in the clear quite yet however.

Prior to the invention of the pecan sheller,
pecan shelling was one of the most dangerous
and low paying jobs in America.

With hazards such as inhaling pecan dust and
pay as low as $1-4 a week, many of the shellers
walked out and commenced a 2 month long strike.

The strike may have ended in their favor,
but it wasn’t long after that the new invention

replaced them and removed the need for the
job entirely.

Following the modern trend, the modern versions
of pecan pie we know of today only came into

existence because of a little recipe included
on a bottle.

Karo corn syrup began including their recipe
for pecan pie using their syrup around the

The product and recipe were a massive success,
essentially becoming the basis for any pecan
pie recipe you come across today.

And despite our current health practices advising
consumers to opt out of the corn syrup in

favor of molasses or brown sugar, Texans still
love their pecan pie.

It became their official state dessert in
2013, even with some suggesting that the pie

cannot have chocolate or must be made with
only Texas pecans.

Uuuuhh, that’s a bit of an oopies on my
part because this recipe here has a decent
layer of chocolate.

I figured it would be a nice nod to some other
famous Texan desserts like German chocolate
cake, sheet cake, and more!

There just too many desserts to choose from
so let me know what state and what dessert
you wanna see next!
